Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Inorganic Phase Change Materials Embedded in Closed-Cell Foams
Award.AbstractNarration:
This Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project will result in the development of an additive for spray polyurethane foam (SPF) insulation that absorbs heat on warm days, reducing cooling needs and lowering construction and operational energy costs. The additive consists of cheap raw materials, and the company is designing a synthesis process that will minimize production complexity and costs. The resulting insulation additive composite will perform up to 40% more effectively than existing SPF. Thus, in hot climates, the amount of insulation needed can be reduced, resulting in zero-day payback for customers. This upends the current economics of PCM products, which ordinarily require a substantial upfront investment and a long payback period. Furthermore, the adoption of these additives will lower the electricity needed to cool the building, shrinking its environmental footprint. In addition, the composite will be applied during construction in the same way as SPF, reducing barriers to adoption. The total North American market for insulation is $11 billion per year. SPF makes up 9%, or $990 million, of this market, and is growing by 5% per year.

The intellectual merit of this project lies in the use of inexpensive inorganic phase-change materials (PCMs) in the insulation additive, and the drop-in nature of the additive. Most PCM-enhanced building materials on the market use organic PCMs, which although easy to process, are expensive and flammable. In addition, the application of these materials is incompatible with existing construction processes. In contrast, the product to be developed in this effort uses cheaper inorganic PCMs that are flame retardant, and the additive will be easily applied during construction as a composite with SPF insulation. Inorganic PCMs usually suffer from a lack of thermal reversibility, meaning that they cannot cycle daily and would not be useful as a building material. However, we have developed an innovative processing method that creates small particles that are thermally reversible. The company's current research focuses on mixing the additive into polyurethane foam in a drop-in process, using the hydrophobic foam as protection for the additive from leakage and atmospheric water vapor that may degrade the additive. By working with spray foam manufacturers, the team will adjust properties of the additive to ensure compatibility with SPF and its precursors, and a long lifespan for the resulting composite.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Air conditioning accounts for 14% of retail building energy costs in the US. What if buildings could cool themselves? At CoolComposites, we invented CoolFluxTM—a new material technology that passively reduces the amount of heat that travels into a building during a hot day. At the core of CoolFlux is an inorganic Phase Change Material (PCM), which like ice, melts at high temperatures, and solidifies at low temperature. However, unlike ice, CoolFlux melts near room temperatures so it can automatically keep buildings comfortable. On a hot day, the melting PCM absorbs heat that would have otherwise traveled into a home, office, or warehouse building. At night, when the outside temperature is low, the PCM solidifies (like ice in a freezer), recharging so that it can absorb heat again the next day. Our modeling shows that incorporating CoolFlux into polyurethane insulation costs only 20% more to install, but that doing so can reduce air conditioning costs by 40%, granting consumers short installation payback periods and long-term cost and energy savings.

          CoolFlux is different from many other PCM technologies because it uses inorganic phase change materials, whereas most available PCMs use organic phase change materials. Organic PCMs are easy to make and are reliable to use, and can be found in a variety of products that require temperature control; such as coffee mugs, foam mattresses, and high-performance sportswear.  Unfortunately, organic PCMs are expensive and flammable, which prevents them from being implemented at larger scales into building insulation. Inorganic PCMs are cheaper than organic PCMs and can absorb more energy, but are less reliable at re-solidifying, and they also need to be carefully protected from environmental humidity and contamination. At CoolComposites, our scientists and engineers devised clever materials strategies to chemically modify CoolFlux so that it recharges quickly and reliably. We also developed new processing techniques to surround each microparticle with a thin plastic shell, to insulate the PCM from the environment. When we incorporated these encapsulated, cyclable inorganic PCM microparticles into polyurethane, we found that heat transport through the insulation could be dramatically reduced.

         At CoolComposites, our next goal is be to take our product from the lab to the market. We are designing a manufacturing plant to scale up production of CoolFlux, so that it can be sold as an additive material into existing insulation solutions. Our goal is to integrate CoolFlux into the building insulation and insulation retrofitting markets in America over the next 5 years. In 2017 we plan to hire new scientists, technicians and salespeople to grow our company, and build a pilot production plant near our headquarters in Boston, MA. This work was enabled by the funding support from the Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Grant, led by the National Science Foundation.
